entry.title: Hello World
entry.content:
Welcome to Hexo! This is your very first post. Check documentation for more info. If you get any problems when using Hexo, you can find the answer in troubleshooting or you can ask me on GitHub.

#Specifies the value for maximum file descriptors that can be opened by this process.

http
{

View/Camera Transformation

  • How to take a photo

    • Find a good place and arrange people(model transformation)
    • Find a good â€œangleâ€ to put the camera(view transformation)
    • Cheese!(projection transformation)

  • Define the camera first

    • Position eâƒ—\vec{e}e
    • Look-at / gaze direction g^\hat{g}g^â€‹
    • Up direction t^\hat{t}t^ (assuming perp. to look-at)

  • Key observation

    • If the camera and all objects move together, the â€œphotoâ€ will be the same

  • How about that we always transform the camera to

    • The origin, up at Y, look at -Z
    • And transform the objects along with the camera

  • Transform the camera by Mview

    • So itâ€™s located at the origin, up at Y, look at -Z

  • Mview in math?

    • Translate e to origin
    • Rotates g to -Z
    • Rotates t to Y
    • Rotates (g x t) To X
    • Letâ€™s write Mview=RviewTview å…ˆå¹³ç§»å†çº¿æ€§å˜æ¢

    Tview=(100âˆ’xe010âˆ’ye001âˆ’ze0001)T_{view}= \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 & 0 & 0 & -x_e\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -y_e\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -z_e\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) Tviewâ€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹1000â€‹0100â€‹0010â€‹âˆ’xeâ€‹âˆ’yeâ€‹âˆ’zeâ€‹1â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹

    • Translate e to origin

    • Rotate g to -Z, t to Y, (g Ã—\timesÃ— t) to X

    • Consider its inverse rotation: X to (g Ã—\timesÃ— t), Y to t, Z to -g

    • Rviewâˆ’1R_{view}^{-1}Rviewâˆ’1â€‹æ€ä¹ˆå¾—åˆ°çš„ï¼Ÿ

      • ä¸¾ä¾‹ï¼šX(1,0,0)Tâ‹…Rviewâˆ’1=(gâƒ—Ã—tâƒ—)X(1,0,0)^T\cdot R_{view}^{-1}=(\vec{g}\times\vec{t})X(1,0,0)Tâ‹…Rviewâˆ’1â€‹=(gâ€‹Ã—t)

    • Rviewâˆ’1=(xg^Ã—t^xtxâˆ’g0yg^Ã—t^ytyâˆ’g0zg^Ã—t^ztzâˆ’g00001)â†’Rview=(xg^Ã—t^yg^Ã—t^zg^Ã—t^0xtytzt0xâˆ’gyâˆ’gzâˆ’g00001)R_{view}^{-1}= \left( \begin{array}{c} x_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & x_t & x_{-g} & 0\\ y_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & y_t & y_{-g} & 0\\ z_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & z_t & z_{-g} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) \rightarrow R_{view}= \left( \begin{array}{c} x_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & y_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & z_{\hat{g}\times\hat{t}} & 0\\ x_t & y_t & z_t & 0\\ x_{-g} & y_{-g} & z_{-g} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) Rviewâˆ’1â€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹xg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹yg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹zg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹0â€‹xtâ€‹ytâ€‹ztâ€‹0â€‹xâˆ’gâ€‹yâˆ’gâ€‹zâˆ’gâ€‹0â€‹0001â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹â†’Rviewâ€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹xg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹xtâ€‹xâˆ’gâ€‹0â€‹yg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹ytâ€‹yâˆ’gâ€‹0â€‹zg^â€‹Ã—t^â€‹ztâ€‹zâˆ’gâ€‹0â€‹0001â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹

  • Summary

    • Until cameraâ€™s at the origin, up at Y, look at -Z

Orthographic Projection

  • A simple way of understanding

    • Camera located at origin,looking at -Z, up at Y
    • Drop Z coordinate
    • Translate and scale the resulting rectangle to [-1,1]2

  • In general

    • We want to map a cuboid [l,r]Ã—\timesÃ—[b,t]Ã—\timesÃ—[f,n] to the "canonical(æ­£åˆ™ã€è§„èŒƒã€æ ‡å‡†)"cube [-1,1]3

    • Slightly different orders (to the â€œsimple wayâ€)

      • Center cuboid by translation
      • Scale into â€œcanonicalâ€ cube

    • Translate (center to origin) first, then scale (length/width/height to 2)

    • Mortho=(2râˆ’l00002tâˆ’b00002nâˆ’f00001)â‹…(100âˆ’r+l2010âˆ’t+b2001âˆ’n+f20001)M_{ortho}= \left( \begin{array}{c} \frac{2}{r-l} & 0 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & \frac{2}{t-b} & 0 & 0\\ 0 & 0 & \frac{2}{n-f} & 0\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) \cdot \left( \begin{array}{c} 1 & 0 & 0 & -\frac{r+l}{2}\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & -\frac{t+b}{2}\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & -\frac{n+f}{2}\\ 0 & 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right) Morthoâ€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹râˆ’l2â€‹000â€‹0tâˆ’b2â€‹00â€‹00nâˆ’f2â€‹0â€‹0001â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹â‹…ââœâœâ›â€‹1000â€‹0100â€‹0010â€‹âˆ’2r+lâ€‹âˆ’2t+bâ€‹âˆ’2n+fâ€‹1â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹

Perspective Projection

  • Most common in Computer Graphics, art, visual system

  • Further objects are smaller

  • Parallel lines not parallel; converge to single point

  • How to perspective projection

    • First â€œsquishâ€ the frustum into a cuboid(n->n,f->f)(Mperspâˆ’>orthoM_{persp->ortho}Mperspâˆ’>orthoâ€‹)
    • Do orthograpgics projection(MorthoM_{ortho}Morthoâ€‹ ,already know!)

  • In order to find a transform

    • Recall the key idea: Find the relationship between transformed points(xâ€™,yâ€™,zâ€™) and the original points(x,y,z)
    • xâ€²=nzxx' = \frac{n}{z}xxâ€²=znâ€‹x {similar to yâ€™}

  • In homogeneous coordinates

  • So the â€œsquishâ€ (persp to ortho) projection does this

    • Mperspâ†’ortho(xyz1)=(nxnyunknownz)M_{persp\rightarrow ortho} \left( \begin{array}{c} x\\ y\\ z\\ 1 \end{array} \right)= \left( \begin{array}{c} nx\\ ny\\ unknown\\ z \end{array} \right) Mperspâ†’orthoâ€‹ââœâœâ›â€‹xyz1â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹nxnyunknownzâ€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹

  • Already good enough to figure out part of Mperspâ†’orthoM_{persp\rightarrow ortho}Mperspâ†’orthoâ€‹

    • Mperspâ†’ortho=(n0000n00????0010)M_{persp\rightarrow ortho}= \left( \begin{array}{c} n & 0 & 0 & 0\\ 0 & n & 0 & 0\\ ? & ? & ? & ?\\ 0 & 0 & 1 & 0 \end{array} \right) Mperspâ†’orthoâ€‹=ââœâœâ›â€‹n0?0â€‹0n?0â€‹00?1â€‹00?0â€‹â âŸâŸââ€‹

    • Any information that we can user?

  • Observation: the third row is responsible for zâ€™

    • Any point on the near plane will not change
    • Any pointâ€™s z on the far plane will not change

  • So the third row must be of the form(0 0 A B)

  • What do we know now?

  • Any pointâ€™s z on the far plane will not change

  • Solve for A and B

  • Finally, every thing in Mperspâ†’orthoM_{persp\rightarrow ortho}Mperspâ†’orthoâ€‹ is known!

  • Whatâ€™s next?

    • Do orthographic projection(Mortho) to finish
    • Mpersp=MorthoMperspâ†’orthoM_{persp}=M_{ortho}M_{persp\rightarrow ortho}Mperspâ€‹=Morthoâ€‹Mperspâ†’orthoâ€‹

Sampling Artifacts in Computer Graphics

  • Artifacts due to sampling - â€œAliasingâ€

    • Jaggies - samping in space

    • Moire - undersampling images

    • Wagon wheel effect - sampling in time

    • [Many more]â€¦

  • Behind the Aliasing Artifacts

    • Signals are changing too fast(high frequency) but sampled too slowly

    • Essentially still â€œnot enough samplesâ€ problems
    • DLSS(Deep Learning Super Sampling)

Specular reflection

  • V close to mirror direction ç›¸ä¼¼ half vector near normal

    • Measure â€œnearâ€ by dot product of unit vectors

    • ä¸Šé¢çš„æŒ‡æ•°p æ˜¯æ ¹æ®è§’åº¦ä¸ä½™å¼¦å€¼å…³ç³»åŠ ä¸Šçš„ï¼Œå‡å°å®¹å¿åº¦ã€‚Incresing p narrows the reflection lobe. Pè¶Šå¤§ï¼Œé«˜å…‰èŒƒå›´è¶Šå°

Ambient Reflection

  • Shading that does not depend on anything

    • Add constant color to account for disregarded illumination and fill in black shadows
    • This is approximate / fake!

Shading Frequencies

  • ä»å·¦åˆ°å³

    • Flat Shadingæ¯ä¸ªå¹³é¢è®¡ç®—ä¸€ä¸ªæ³•çº¿

      • Triangle face is flat - one normal vector
      • Not good for smooth surfaces

    • Gouraud shadingæ¯ä¸ªé¡¶ç‚¹è®¡ç®—ä¸€ä¸ªæ³•çº¿ç„¶ååšæ’å€¼

      • Interpolate colors from vertices across triangle
      • Each vertex has a normal vector(how?)

    • Phong shadingæ¯ä¸ªåƒç´ è®¡ç®—ä¸€ä¸ªæ³•çº¿

      • Interpolate normal vectors across each triangle
      • Compute full shading model at each pixel
      • Not the Blinn-Phong Reflectance Model

Shader Programs

  • Program vertex and fragment processing stages
  • Describe operation on a single vertex(or fragment)
  • Example GLSL fragment shader program
    • Shader function executes once per fragment.

  • æŠ•å½±å‰è®¡ç®—å‡ºæ¥çš„ä¸­å¿ƒåæ ‡æ— æ³•æŠ•å½±åˆ°æŠ•å½±åè®¡ç®—å‡ºçš„ä¸­å¿ƒåæ ‡(è¦åœ¨æŠ•å½±ä¹‹å‰è®¡ç®—å‡ºæ¥é‡å¿ƒ)

Applying Texture

Texture Magnification(What if the texture is too small?) - Easy Case(çº¹ç†æ¯”å›¾åƒåˆ†è¾¨ç‡å°çš„é—®é¢˜)

Generally donâ€™t want this - insufficient texture resolution

A pixel on a texture - a texel(çº¹ç†å…ƒç´ ã€çº¹ç´ )

  • åŒçº¿æ€§æ’å€¼
    • Bilnear interpolation usually gives pretty good results at reasonable costs

Texture Magnification(What if the texture is too large) - hard case(çº¹ç†æ¯”å›¾åƒåˆ†è¾¨ç‡å¤§çš„é—®é¢˜)

Mipmap Allowing(fast,approx.,square) range queries

  • é¢å¤–çš„ä¸‰åˆ†ä¹‹ä¸€å­˜å‚¨

Computing Mipmap Level D

  • å¯¹æ˜ å°„è¿‡å»çš„æ­£æ–¹å½¢åšè¿‘ä¼¼ï¼Œåº”ç”¨Mipmap Allowingå°†çŸ©å½¢å˜æˆç¬¬Då±‚çš„1$\times$1çŸ©å½¢ï¼Œæ˜ å°„åˆ°ä¸€ä¸ªåƒç´ ä¸­

Visualization of Mipmap Level

  • å•çº¯çš„æ˜ å°„æ•ˆæœä¸å¥½ï¼Œå› ä¸ºmipmapå–å±‚æ•°æ˜¯ç¦»æ•£çš„ï¼Œä¼šå‡ºç°é—´æ–­çš„çº¿

å› æ­¤å¯åšä¸€æ¬¡ä¸‰çº¿æ€§æ’å€¼ï¼Œå–è¿ç»­æ’å€¼å±‚texel(çº¹ç†å…ƒç´ ï¼Œçº¹ç´ )

Trilinear Interpolation

  • åœ¨ç›¸é‚»ä¸¤å±‚ä¸­å„åšåŒçº¿æ€§æ’å€¼ï¼Œç„¶åå°†ç»“æœå†åšä¸€æ¬¡çº¿æ€§æ’å€¼ã€‚

  • ä½†è¿™æ ·åšæ•ˆæœå¹¶ä¸å¥½ï¼Œè¿œå¤„çš„ç»†èŠ‚éƒ½ä¼šæ¨¡ç³Š(Overblur)ï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ä¸‹é¢æ¥æ”¹å–„

Anisotropic Filtering(å„å‘å¼‚æ€§è¿‡æ»¤)

Ripmaps and summed area tables
  • Can look up axis-aligned rectangular zones
  • Diagonal footprints still a problem

Irregular Pixel Footprint in Texture(ä¸ç”¨æ°´å¹³ç«–ç›´éƒ½å‹ç¼©ï¼Œå¯ä»¥åªå‹ç¼©ä¸€ä¸ªæ–¹å‘),ä½†æ˜¯è¿˜æœ‰ä¸€äº›æƒ…å†µæ²¡èƒ½è§£å†³ï¼Œæ¯”å¦‚æ˜ å°„è¿‡å»è¦†ç›–çš„æ˜¯ä¸€ç§æ–œç€çš„é•¿æ¡

EWA filtering
  • Use multiple lookups
  • Weighted average
  • Mipmap hierarchy still helps
  • Can handle irredular footprints

Many, Many Uses for Texturing

In modern GPUs, texture = memory + range query(filtering)

  • General method to bring data to fragment calculations

Textures can affect shading!

  • Texture doesnâ€™t have to only represent colors
    • What if it stores the height/normal?
    • Bump / normal mapping
    • Fake the detailed geometry

Bump Mapping

Adding surface detail without adding more triangles

  • Perturb surface normal per pixel(for shading computations only)

  • â€œHeight shiftâ€ per texel defined by a texture

  • How to modify normal vector?

How to perturb the normal(in flatland)

  • Original surface normal nÂ§ = (0,1)
  • Derivative at p is dp = c * [h(p+1) - hÂ§]
  • Perturbed normal is then nÂ§ = (-dp,1).normalized()

How to perturb the normal (in 3D)

  • Original surface normal nÂ§ = (0,0,1)
  • Derivatives at p are
    • dp/dv = c1* [h(u+1) - h(u)]
    • dp/dv = c2 * [h(v+1) - h(v)]
  • Perturbed normal is n = (-dp/du, -dp/dv,1).normalized()
  • Note that this is in local coordinate!

Displacement mapping

a more advanced approach

  • Uses the same texture as in bumping mapping
  • Actually moves the vertices

ä¸‰ã€Geometry

Many Ways to Represent Geometry

  • Implicit
    • algebraic surface
    • level sets
    • distance functions
  • Explicit
    • point cloud
    • polugon mesh
    • subdivision,NURBS

â€œImplicitâ€ Representations of Geometry

Based on classifying points

  • Points satisfy some specified relationship

E.g. sphere: all points in 3D,where x2+y2+z2=1

More generally,f(x,y,z) = 0

â€œExplicitâ€ Representations of Geometry

All points are given directly or via parameter mapping

Implicit

Algebraic Surfaces(Implicit)

Surface is zero set of a polynomial in x,y,z

Constructive Solid Geometry(Implicit)

Combine implicit geometry via Boolean operations

Distance Fuctions(Implicit)

Instead of Booleans, gradually blend surfaces together using

  • Distance fuctions:

    giving minimum distance(could be signed distance) from anywhere to object

Level Set Methods

Closed-form equations are hard to describe complex shapes

Alternative: store a grid of values approximating function

Surface is found where interpolated values equal zero

Provides much more explicit control over shape(like a texture)

Fractals(Implicit)(åˆ†å½¢)

Exhibit selt-similarity, detail at all scales

â€œLanguageâ€ for describing natural phenomena

Hard to control shape!

Implicit Representations - Pros & Cons

  • Pros:
    • compact description(e.g., a fuction)
    • certain queries easy(inside object, distance to surface)
    • good for ray-to-surface intersection(more later)
    • for simple shapes, exact description / no sampling error
    • easy to handle changes in topology(e.g., fluid)
  • Cons:
    • difficult to model complex shapes

Explicit

Point Cloud

Easiest representation: list of points(x,y,z)

Polygon Mesh

Store vertices & polygons(often triangles or quads)

Easier to do processing/simulation,adaptive sampling

More complicated data structures

Perhaps most common representation in graphics

Curves

Bezier Curves(è´å¡å°”æ›²çº¿)

  • Defining Cubic Bezier Curve With Tangents

æ›²çº¿è¦ç»è¿‡èµ·æ­¢ç‚¹

  • de Casteljau Algorithm
